titleStmt.title:
Suppos'd to be writ by Mr Swift.
The place of the Damn'd.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l:
\the following remarks are written路toward the close of a letter from J. T. to an unknown correspondent. In a different eighteenth-century hand, the letter is docketed Nov: 27: 1731
place of the Damnd.\ here is a pretty deal of scandall flying about in a poetical dress as usual, but I believe you have \no路inserted路with路caret\ inclination to read that wch I have no stomach to write. but the following verses wch are pretty rank Satyr may possibly give yu a little diversion
All folke who pretend to religion or grace
Allow there's a hell, but dispute of the place.
Yet if hell may by logical rules be defind,
The place of the damn'd; 'Ile tell you my mind.
Wherever the damn'd do most cheifly abound,
Most certainly there is a hell to be found.
Damn'd Poets, damn'd Criticks, damn'd Blockheads & knaves,
Damn'd Senators brib'd & damn'd prostitute Slaves,
Damn'd Lawyers, damn'd Judges, damn'd Lords & damn'd Squire\s\
Damn'd Spys & Informers, damn'd friends & damn'd ly\overwriting\es
Damn'd Villains corrupted in ev'ry Station
Damn'd time serving preists all over the nation,
om.
om.
om.
om.
And into the bargain I'le readily give yee
Damn'd ignorant Prelates & councellors privy,
Then let us no more by the Parson be flam'd,
Wee may know by these tokens the place of the damn'd,
Then Hell to be sure is at Paris or Rome,
And happy for us that it is not at home.
